reviewText:
This arena shooter is so much fun and looks delicious.
Sadly the developers dropped support for it and it wasn't playable online for a long time.

Now the game got re-released in the Steam Store and the player base is gone.
Seriously, either no soul is online or the servers are not reachable.

I sadly can't recommend this game, because the developers are obviously not capable of maintaining it properly.
I'd like more people to own this, so the player base grows, but first there should be functioning servers...

Developers, fix your ♥♥♥♥. Thanks.

reviewText: Amazing game, really faced fast arena shooter in similar vein of unreal/quake with sci-fi setting and varied levels. The game looks good and the audio is crisp and clean, the mutators are a integral part of the game and makes the game so much fun, you chose from 3 different random options and there are plenty of those to keep it random and fun at the same time.\n\nThis game was relaunched after a long time due to the old publishers (THQ) shutting down the servers as they went bankript which is a shame, the problem still with the game is that it still has optimization issues and the biggest problem of populated servers, the game literally has 8-10 people playing at during its peak while has even zero during down time which is a real shame coz this is one of those highly underrated titles that i am sure many people would love to play as we dont have many mp games in the similar genre these days.
voteText: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game is extremely underrated. If you're a fan of old-school Arena FPS such as Quake you will absolutely love this. This game is the Quake of modern times and needs a bigger userbase. If you like the genre, BUY IT!
The movement system of this game is possibily the smoothest and nicest one I've ever seen. It's even better than Quake's movement system. You have an extreme control of your trajectory in mid air, for example you can rotate by 90 degrees in mid air and change your trajectory with a sharp turn. You can accelerate slightly by jumping (similar to bunnyhopping).
The maps are AWESOME and there is custom maps support - users can create their own maps and share them with the community.
The graphics are next-gen but I don't really care, I prefer keeping them at minimum because all the nextgen effects and shading distract me.
For the first time ever, I like a modern game as much or even more than Quake, trust me.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
If you love fast paced first person shooters then look no further!

This game has been released once more and I am happy it can finally be played by people who may have missed it the first time round. It plays a lot like UT and Quake but has its own unique style and it looks beautiful when maxed out, the way Cryengine 3 is meant to be used.

Hopefully the online community comes back to this as it desperatley misses it. I also highly recommend Duel Mode with a friend, 1v1, Instagib with the Nex; prepare for one frantic butt clenching game!

Welcome back Nexuiz!

column16: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I used to play Nexuiz classic all the time, and remember packed servers and fast paced UT-like action, was excited to see the re-release on steam.

After almost a week of logging in and searching here and there i STILL havent found a single multiplayer game to join, and the bots are just boring.  I even sat in an empty server for 3 hours waiting for someone to join but it never happened, without players there's no real point in picking this up.

Aside from that there are some other issues too, the weapons all kinda look the same and hud  (especially the weapon indicators) are in a really bad spot.  The mutators feature while interesting for about 5 minutes gets annoying fast and i can't really see keeping that on ever.  Visually the game kinda looks cluttered, not nearly as bad as most modern fps games but still a huge step down in visual clarity from nex classic/UT99-2004 (think oversaturated overdetailed maps like the stock UT3 ones where the details just end up getting in the way of playing)

Might be worth picking up cheap if a community ever starts to form, but honestly it seems almost too late at this point.

reviewText: A fantastic arena style FPS - a variety of levels, weapons, low gravity modes - really resembles the new Doom (2016). There are hardly no hiding spots in these levels. Highly suggested and cheap.

reviewText:
Final Impressions:

The Medal Master achivement appears, presently, to be unachiveable, as no medals seem to be produced from bot matches and there are insufficient players for proper pvp/quick matches.
The issue with speed vs. fire rate for several weapons still seems to apply (not a lag issue) and this is unfortunate and makes, at least for me, a handful of the weapons totally useless.

I would recommend this game if it were picked up in a bundle and/or certainly if it becomes free. As a standalone purchase however, this game has an insufficient player base to justify the expense.

I suggest to the developers:

1. Hold some Nexuiz events to better market this older title

2. Decrease the stand-alone price and/or add in some additional DLC (between your more active projects) to increase it's cost vs. benefit rating

3. Actively seek to include the title in other bundles to increase availability and perhaps expand the player base (I acquired the game via the Cryengine dev pack on Humble bundle for example).

I am changing the rating on this review to a positive one--as I do find myself playing the game and that, unto itself, speaks volumes.

Third impressions:

Nexuiz is slowly growing on me. No real online multi-player (lack of population). Still having issues with aiming--given run/jump speeds etc. I have yet to receive any medals--so I believe this remains glitched and may have to be worked around for the achivement to trigger for pokemon purposes. Fun for short bursts, but still can't recommend it as an individual purchase at this time.

Second impressions:

CTF is definately the best match type so far--such has remained enjoyable.

Hitbox/accuracy remains an issue--the raw/base movement of characters still seems to surpass actual projectile speed (does not seem to be a lag/graphic setting issue, but more play is needed).

Mutators are enjoyable and afford an excellent, and in a couple instances--funny, variation to some of the other arena games I have played.

Tried some online quick matches. Player population remains very limited. One game was fine (albeit a loss) the other has me questioning how prevalent hacking is amonst the minute player base (1-2 shot kills 8 times in a row within 10s of respawning, and whilst on the run, seems a tad high--but then I am new to this product. However, such was not noticed in any bot matches or my other online/pvp matches to date).

First impressions:

Acquired via the Cryengine Humble Bundle.

Maps are generally well designed. CTF is fun, however, DM is, unfortunately, quite bland.

Both CTF and DM suffer, from what is intended to be a feature, by the ADHD style of movement within Nexuiz. Yes it is fast paced, but so much so that it is more about spray and pray" than actual aiming/accuracy.

The frequency of powerups/drops et al. is also very high on the maps I've explored to date. This makes resource conservation of little value
recommended: and further supports the "spray and pray" style.\n\nIf you want arena combat
hoursPlayed: akin to Speedy gonzales running around with a rocket launcher
voteText: then Nexuiz fits the bill.\n\nI remain hopeful I'll see some value
votesHelpful: in Nexuiz and I will update this review accordingly as additional play time is logged."

reviewText:
Nexuiz is a fast paced arena type shooter utilizing cry engine 3 giving it a beautiful graphical display. There are several unique weapons rannging from the nex, your classic railgun sniper to the rocket launcher. Thus far the game has 3 modes.

Capture the flag and team dm being the standard modes with a DLC that adds in 1v1 duel mode. Ontop of that you can pick up mutators which change how the game is played by making everything black and white, making your opponets mute so they cant hear and adding in the dev's floating heads that shoot lazers. Around the map there are armour pick up sort of like in quake which are essential to your survival.

All and all I enjoyed playing this game, there are a few bugs and the lack of a community and difficulty finding a game with more then 3 people but if you have a friend to play with i reccomend this game though if your looking to play online I wouldn't bother picking it up due to lack of community.

reviewText:
Don't bother with this game.  This is not an arena FPS. Poor maps, poor weapons, poor optimization, unbalanced gameplay with over 100 random mutators etc. It's a mess more suited for people who like ROTT 2013 multiplayer.

If you truly  like Unreal Tournament and Quake, stay the fukk away from this and instead check out Toxikk and Reflex respectively.

There are much better AFPS games out there. Check out /r/ArenaFPS to be enlightened.

I'm sorry but I just can't recommend it.  It's a shame because I really wanted to like this game.

The Steam version of Nexuiz has got better graphics than the original, free to play -client for sure, but having played the original game for several years, I found the new commercial version to be a bit of a miss for me.

These graphical improvements have made the game feel less tactile in my opinion. The Quakeish feel is still there, but it feels somewhat bloated now. It is however more likely to attract the new generation of gamers with aforementioned in-your-face graphics and dubstep-filled loading screens.

If you're looking for yet another reaction shooter and don't mind recycled content or just have the desire to pay more for the polished look, go for it. I'd recommend getting to know the alternatives first though. Unreal Tournament 3 is definitely worth the extra dough.

Awesome. Brings back good old fast-pased combat. Considering release date of latest Quake and Unreal, this is an exelent alternative. Shame that all servers are DEAD.

A great, super fast paced arena shooter. Very good graphics, tons of settings to tweak, and as far from a console port as you can get. If your looking for something along the lines of Quake 4, or UT3 then this is your game. LAN party support built in. Only downfall is the 4 player per-side limit making this game only support 8 players at a time.

A great arena shooter with beautiful visuals :D!

What makes this unique from the likes of Quake and Unreal Tournament are the mutators you pick up around the map which change the way you/your team/everyone plays the game for a set amount of time. There's exactly 100 of them that traverse from upping your attack/defence strength, upping your movement speed and jump height, lowering gravity, giving everyone jetpacks, and a heap more.

These mutators give all players the opportunity to get ahead in a match, all it takes is a good mutator and a steady trigger finger. I've heard one guy call it the Mario Party of arena shooters. It pretty much is minus the slow pace of Mario Party. Nexuiz is quite fast paced :D
Is a little Unreal Tournament Wanna be" but it's fun

reviewText: I love the graphics style. This should be pretty enjoyable for any Unreal or Quake fan just smaller matches.\n

It was a good effort. I think the devs were trying to make a modern-day Quake Arena, but it doesn't play well. It rendered very slowly, even on low, and the game is supposed to be fast paced. There's also a lot of motion-blur that you can't really turn off, and motion-blur combined with low framerates is just a mess.\n\nI liked the weapons, and the graphics were nice while you were standing still. That's about all, unfortunately.

Nexuiz is a competent futuristic tournament combat game with demanding although attractive DirectX11 graphics.  As is often the case with tournament combat games, the backstory is paper thin and serves only to briefly explain the futuristic setting.  While the combat is quick paced, and there are a variety of fun mutators like super jumps or unlimited ammo, the game unfortunately looks and feels almost identical to Unreal Tournament 2004.  This may not be a bad thing for fans of the genre because the game will immediately feel familiar, but I found myself growing bored quickly and the lackluster weapon effects and HUD did not do much to encourage my enthusiasm.  That said, it is a competent entry in the genre but the lack of a single player campaign, steep system requirements, and rather lackluster gameplay should keep all but genre diehards away.

Very cool arena FPS, top notch graphics, lots of mutators which make the game very interesting, too bad the game was DOA,, no more than 10-15 players playing at any given time, too bad because the game had lots of potential, perhaps a Steam Free Weekend can build a community.

A FPS that tries to be Unreal Tournament, Quake 3 and Halo all in one and it fails miserabley at it. This game was made to be a competitive arena shooter but yet it uses a random mutator system. That would be like a pro baseball team playing competitively with a  random chance that the opposing team could hit a grand slam off of a base hit. If 8 friends want to get together and just blast and have goofy fun, then ok but serious competitors, steer clear. Now that a patch has been released the gameplay is smooth and the weapons work well. All and All not a bad game just confused at what it wants to be. My score is for  the BOT or playing with friends side of the game. Rating 6 out of 10

An arena shooter with a bit of a twist. In Nexuiz, matches are punctuated by the use of mutators which change the flow of the game. For instance, there is a mutator that lowers gravity allowing you to jump great distances, another that gives everyone sniper rifles and enforces one hit kills. In total, there are 100 mutators. They are the best aspect of Nexuiz, making matches unpredictable and exciting.

It is a multiplayer game at heart (you can only play bot matches single player) which makes the problems with the online all the more confounding. The hit detection is very suspect; you can be unleashing on an opponent but seemingly do no damage. There is a fair bit of lag usually, so it exacerbates the hit detection issues. The player base is tiny too, thus it can be very difficult to find matches.

It's good for a couple of hours play, not much more.

ok so wow....downloaded this game today the community app it comes with RAPTR seems awesome and the game HOLY CRAP wow is it fast paced and the mutators dont even get me started great game especially since its on sale DLC and all for like 3.75 dang thats cheap!\n\nBUY THIS NOW !

Forget about hyper realistic military simulators, this is what multiplayer first person shooters should be all about -  ridiculous weapons and fast paced, wildly unrealistic gameplay. Nexuiz is effectively a cross between Unreal Tournament 2004, Tribes: Ascend and Serious Sam 3: BFE. If you enjoy those games, you will most definitely enjoy this. If you're looking for realism, or a 'serious' multiplayer shooter, Battlefield or CoD would be a better option. If you want to actually have fun whilst playing, go for Nexuiz.\n\nRecommendation: BUY NAOW

The Steam version of Nexuiz has got better graphics than the original, free to play -client for sure, but having played the original game for several years, I found the new commercial version to be a bit of a miss for me.

These graphical improvements have made the game feel less tactile in my opinion. The Quakeish feel is still there, but it feels somewhat bloated now. It is however more likely to attract the new generation of gamers with aforementioned in-your-face graphics and dubstep-filled loading screens.

If you're looking for yet another reaction shooter and don't mind recycled content or just have the desire to pay more for the polished look, go for it. I'd recommend getting to know the alternatives first though. Unreal Tournament 3 is definitely worth the extra dough.

The Steam version of Nexuiz has got better graphics than the original, free to play -client for sure, but having played the original game for several years, I found the new commercial version to be a bit of a miss for me.

These graphical improvements have made the game feel less tactile in my opinion. The Quakeish feel is still there, but it feels somewhat bloated now. It is however more likely to attract the new generation of gamers with aforementioned in-your-face graphics and dubstep-filled loading screens.

If you're looking for yet another reaction shooter and don't mind recycled content or just have the desire to pay more for the polished look, go for it. I'd recommend getting to know the alternatives first though. Unreal Tournament 3 is definitely worth the extra dough.

Used to play this a lot on Xbox 360, and I snagged a key as a part of their current promotion. It's a pretty competent little arena shooter, here's some quick pros and cons:

Pros:
+Pretty nice looking, especially given it's age.
+Gun mechanics are solid and consistent, a must for any arena shooter.
+Map design is pretty solid.
+Bots are present and provide a decent amount of challenge if you crank the difficulty up.

Cons:
-Not really any players at all. Which sucks, because this game has competitive potential. You'll be playing bots or your friends who own the game, and not really anyone else.
-Menus are bland and often confusing to use, especially so when setting up custom matches.
-Occasional bugs, nothing game breaking however.

Questionable Things:
-The randomized mutators. While they are fun, you have to turn them off to get any true competitive play, because their random nature upsets the game balance more often than not.

So, all in all, it's a competent game. I recommend it because it does have bot play, and it's not too pricey. It'll at least scratch your arena shooter itch until UT4 comes out of Alpha.

The game's somewhat amusing mutator feature does very little to hide the fact that is one of the wonkiest arena shooters ever made and I have no idea who would play this considering loads of alternatives exist. Especially including the game's original freeware version, updated and renamed to Xonotic.

I'll be damned, this game is actually back from the grave! Now if only all the players would come back to populate the servers...

Whether you like the game comes down to only 1 thing: how much you like the crazy Nexuiz mutators. These change the game drastically, sometimes affecting all players. Of course, there are also game modes without these mutators, but this is what makes the game special.

Some examples:

- All players get jetpacks.
- Controls are inverted for everyone!
- 1 random player loses his weapons and becomes a living bomb. You can kill lots of players with a kamikaze (although most of the time it's rather annoying)
- Color blind mutator literally changes everything to a greyscale. You'll have trouble telling teams apart. Friendly fire is on.
- Everyone can only use melee for a few secs
- Ground suddenly feels like ice and everyone is sliding (careful around edges ^^)
- Nuke. Everyone dies, then respawns.
- Invulnerability (only you)
- You get Strength (double damage)
- You get your favorite weapon.
- Shooting teammates now heals them instead!
...

There's many more (about 50?). The global mutators take turns in a stack. The stack can be cleared too. Mutators affecting only you take effect instantly when you pick em up, I believe...

Honestly, it's chaotic as hell and a lot of these mutators are rather unwelcome (kamikaze and nuke). But if you like chaos, you will like this.
